title.narrative: Forest and Farm Facility core support 2013-2017

description.narrative: The Forest&Farm Facility (FFF) är en mekanism för finansiering och kapacitetsbyggande med syfte att stärka producentorganisationer o brett deltagande i skogs- o lantbruksrelaterad politisk dialog o samråd. FFF är en utveckling av de tidigare NFP-Facility och Growing Forest Partnership, men mer inriktad på tvärsektor-samarbete, lokala brukare/rättighetsinnehavare, jämställdhet och inkomstskapande åtgärder.

The Forest&Farm Facility is a mechanism for funding and capacity building to stimulate and strengthen farmers organizations and active multi-stakeholder participation in forest and farm-related policy dialogues. A development of the former NFP-Facility and Growing Forest Partnerships, it's more oriented towards cross-sectoral cooperation, local rights holders, gender equity and income creation.

This intervention aims to strengthen Forest and Farm Producer Organizations (FFPOs), as they are identified as important drivers of change for inclusive local development and natural resources governance, and an important but neglected part of the private sector. FFF intends to increase FFPO’s capacity to organize and to participate in local, regional and national level policy dialogues and decision-making processes, as well as enhance FFPO’s skills, market access and negotiation power. As a result, smallholder, women, community and Indigenous People's groups have improved income and food security from sustainable forest and farm management.

description.narrative: The main result of the contribution is the strengthened organizational capacity which facilitates joint decision making, with results both in increased income and investment, increased resilience and greater participation as well as improved communication with local auhorities and other actors. The contribution consists of three pillars, and some of the key results corresponding to the three pillars will be described individually below. Pillar 1: to strengthen smallholder, women, community and Indigenous People’s producer organizations for business, livelihoods and policy engagement FFF has managed to scale up organisations that consist of, or give support to, FFPO businesses in value chain cluster. Considerable effort was put into strengthening the internal organizational management of FFPOs. New businesses organisations have improved income generation for people covered by pillar 1, and women’s leadership in business has been strengthened. Diversification of income has generated more options, higher prices and larger profits. A business school for other FFPOs has been developed as well. In numbers, FAO reports having provided direct support to 947 FFPOs, covering a total of 30 million members of forest and farm producers. 279 FFPO business plans have been completed, 262 businesses have been diversified or added value and 158 have gained access to new finance (contributing to sustainability in the long term). Pillar 2: to catalyze multi-sectoral policy platforms with governments at local and national levels Nested multi-sectoral policy platforms have achieved policy change at multiple levels, forest land tenure rights have been secured, financial incentive programs have been catalyzed and greater awareness of production issues for FFPOs have been widely spread. New legislation has been approved to advance problematic sectors, and new structures in support of FFPOs have been created. Forest and form product businesses are now actively promoted and nurtured to a larger extent than before. By the numbers, FAO reports having established 51 policy platforms, 33 changes in policies and regulations to the benefit of FFPOs, 100 MUSD of new incentive programmes for FFPOs businesses and 114 new community forests recognized. Pillar 3: to link local voices and learning to the global arena through participatory process, communication and information sharing. The contribution has increased reach beyond FFF core partner countries in communicating the importance of strengthening FFPOs, and has contributed to developing common regional and global policy messages. Examples of FFPOs in action has enhanced the understanding and value of family forestry and these messages and capacities were enhanced through strong networks. During the five years, more than 50 substantial knowledge products were also produced and distributed, such as brochures, briefings, books and toolkits. Spanning all three pillars, concrete examples include Bolivian FFPO producers of coffee, cacao and Amazon receiving government funds, establishing a Guatemalan rural business school of agroforestry with capacity for 90 students, the Farm Forestry Smallholder Producers Association of Kenya joining the Kenya National Farmers Federation with 2,2 million members, strengthening their voice, and round table discussions at commune, district and provincial levels in Vietnam, which included government representatives and resulted in policies that enable collective forest businesses.
